FRIDAY, SEPT. 21, 1898.

We congratulate the electors of East Assiniboia on their having returned the Hon. Mr. Dewdney by acclamation, as well as having secured such a representative as they have in the Minister of the Interior. Mr. Dewdney's entire sympathies are still always with us and the Northmen and we can not evidently look forward to an era of contentment on the part of the settlers, for we believe convinced that the new Minister will take prompt action to remove the difficulties which may be existing in local regulations and will strive faithfully to carry out the wishes of the people and to promote the welfare and prosperity of the country. Although in his present capacities of Lieutenant-Governor and Indian Commissioner many complaints were made against Mr. Dewdney, and those politically opposed to him resorted to every conceivable method to disparage his character, yet they have been unable to prefer one direct charge against him, and to-day, after having for seven years treated his slanderers and villains with the contempt which they deserved, he is now elected in the Territories where he is best known that no one could be found reckless enough to oppose him in the recent election in East Assiniboia.

Yellow fever is raging in Florida and is spreading with amazing rapidity in that State. The fatality is very great.

Last week's papers bring the announcement that the last rail has been laid on the Red River Valley Railway, so that the people of Winnipeg have a line of railway to connect with the C. P. R.

The Northern Pacific has commenced work on the branch line from Winnipeg to Portage and Morris to Brandon. These branches have to be completed by November 1, 1899, under the terms of the agreement recently entered into between the Provincial Government and the Northern Pacific Railway, so that western Manitoba will soon have good railway facilities.

With reference to the Regina and Long Lake road, in which we are more directly interested, the talk is still that all necessary arrangements have been made for its immediate construction through Alberta. We have not yet heard of any contract being let, and as the season is getting late, the probabilities are that nothing will be done this year.

The Greenway Government do not appear to have made a very creditable bargain with the Northern Pacific. The railway company appears to be going to settle. The Government is widely condemned for its action in the matter. In the local Legislature, when the contract was voted on, Mr. Isaac Campbell, M. P., and Mr. McNeil, M. P. F., voted against it. The Greenway-Martin railway deal is condemned by Griz and Toric alike, the Free Press being particularly severe in its criticism of the Government.

On Thursday a party of our folk rode out to the home of Hon. Theo. Makin, Mr. James Haggith, T. N. Campbell, W. R. Gurney and James McKay, succeeded in bringing back 300 lbs. of vicinity beef from Dog Hill. Under the influence of one of the rigs was caught in a regular Dakota cyclone which did considerable damage, but by the abundant use of shaggyapp and portions of under garments the party succeeded in getting back to town. T. N. Campbell got down the last load, but was shot. Next.

The annual Dinner at Island Lake is held at the Methodist Church in that settlement a great success, and the ladies who were instrumental in getting it up were most attentive and most kindly enjoyed by everyone present, and especially the ladies who came from town.

The P. A. C. Band were in attendance and kept things airy all afternoon. The weather was very mild and sunny and quite a crowd was building the church. The drive, both going and coming, was very merry and enjoyable.

GENERAL NEWS.

The following is the latest news regarding the terms of union of Newfoundland into the Dominion of Canada, who were to have left today, but have abandoned the project, owing to the heavy losses for the season. The reason given is that the existence of the present troubles between the United States and Great Britain may tend to prejudice the interests of Newfoundland if she joined the Canadian confederation.

A large number of the fishermen returned by boat from operations in many parts of New Brunswick. While some of them, back again, others returned empty-handed. The hay, oats, and other fodder crops have matured equally as much damage from the continued wet weather, which retarded their growth, as the crops generally.

The Northwest Assembly meets for the transaction of business about the 1st of October. Ross, of Moose Jaw, seems to be the favorite for speaker. The appointment of Mr. MacLelland as minister of the interior was confirmed by the legislative board at Suther-land and Second in East and West Asia. Hamilton, for Albertville, Beta, and Schomberg, for St. John's, were also appointed for Assiniboia West.

The Territorial Council will meet to elect its president on the 23rd. The appointment of Mr. MacLelland as Quebec legislature councillor for Mills Lake was confirmed by the council.

George Puddifoot, the famous quaker, who was attacked by paralysis while playing a game of crib at Kinross, died recently.

The Hon. George L. Stansfield family and suite left Quebec Monday morning for Toronto.

Edward Biddle, of North Fredericks- burg, has been asked to pay $500 or stand a second trial for assault. Mr. McCorle, of the same township, said he had been badly treated by the prisoner in the case to proceed.

The members of the locomotive works at Montreal are negotiating with the government for eight feet of land purchased by the company. If an agreement is reached the company will erect a building for the employees' mess-room and bowling alley.

THE GOVERNORS.

Early last spring Hill & Mason, of Sim- iliana, wrote to Mr. Moore, of Picton, Ontario, for a quantity of the poison which he had recommended for the extermination of the rabbits in Australia. Mr. Moore had heard of its success in destroying "gophers," the pests of this country, and received from him a most encouraging reply. He also sent his own experience, a bottle containing 600 grams of chicken poison, with full in- structions for use, which was followed. Mix the poison with water, allowing the same to lie three or four days to germinate. Then mix with meal or short. The experiments were very successful, and the gentlemen referred to say that they have gained the upper hand of the pests. Many rabbits have been killed from them. Large numbers have been found dead, and an examination proves them to be killed. A few remain- ing around the mission are now far. It is to be hoped that this means of rid- ing the country of such destructive pests will be adopted throughout the province. Mr. Pearsall has kindly offered to give further supplies of the miracle substance to any who desire it.

COMMERCIAL. We think the agricultural societies in this district should do something toward the extermination of these pests, and urge all those in charge so that all correspondence will be got through with and the death toll be raised by the destruction of the pests in the spring. This poison may be also used for the destruction of larger animals than the rabbit, such as swine, calves, etc., and is destructive to sheep and young animals.

TERRITORIAL NEWS

REGINA.

From the Leader, Sept. 9.

Mr. L. O. Houghton, the new wire farmer of Montana for harvest duties for the fall, has been appointed by Mr. R. B. Gordon, resigned.

The first At Home House under the new regime of Gordon & Co., will be held Tuesday next, 11th inst., when Miss Royal will be "At Home" from 4 to 6 p.m.

A call for tenders for the new Mount Polley Mine was issued last week. Tenders received up to the 25th inst.

People driving through rural districts may notice the absence of the usual signs on roadways warning of the dangers of driving at night or during the day. A prominent just came in from the Valley reporting a crop in one case of more than 30 bushels per acre. In addition to the harvest is necessary to cut the grass.

This morning the last rain which the country has seen was on the 17th inst. Since that date the most desirable weather has prevailed, clear and cool nights, and the crops are now in such a fine state that of bringing the entire crop to maturity, but also of giving the land a chance to rest. The harvest and no doubt enhanced opportunity of pushing their harvest operations and achieving in the rich production of our grain and hay.

From the Leader, Sept. 11.

Mr. Macdonald, of the Mark Lewis Express, has returned from his trip to the north today. Mr. Macdonald and Mr. Macdonald have been engaged in the grain trade for many years, and they have always been known for their honesty and integrity. They have been very successful in their business and have built up a large customer base.

On Saturday night there was a joint meeting of the Board of Trade and Town Council to arrange a plan of action to receive the farmers of the coming harvest season. The Mayor and Mr. Macdonald telephoned this morning making arrangements.

FORT MACLEOD.

From the Gazette, Sept. 6.

It is probable that arrangements will be made shortly for a telephone exchange at Macleod.

The Indians were started out of town on the gallop by the police last week, as they had been heard to say that they would not pay against these miscreants who were expected every time a lodge is located near town.

What might have proved a disastrous fire took place at the eastern extremity of the town on Monday last night, or rather about an hour's distance away. Frank Foster's hay stack, containing about ten or twelve tons, caught fire, and in a short time the whole was burned to the ground. A number of citizens turned out, and the police fire brigade with their hose were called upon to help, but all efforts to save the stable or stack were useless. If a high wind had been blowing toward the fire, ending one of the prevailing west winds, the results might have been most disastrous. The cause of the fire is unknown.

CALGARY.

From the Herald, Sept. 5.

Talk about harvest weather! It is difficult to remember what cloudy weather looks like.

Doesn't the dust shooting season appear to open too early? This year ducks will be "hopping" for some time yet, and a large number of these birds' ducklings are being shot, if report speaks truly.

An auspicious day in the history of Calgary and Alberta was the 31st day of August, 1883. Forming an epoch in the annals of the city, the erection of Fort Calgary, as the place was then called, will long be remembered by those who witnessed its rise. The first inhabitant of the City of Calgary was a man named Mr. Smith, who lived in a small house on the banks of the Bow River.

From the Tribune, Sept. 6.

The First Presbyterian Church Society held its annual meeting Friday night at Sandy Wilson's house where the old officers were present. The meeting was a success and between twenty and thirty members attended.

Sheep Creek held their annual meeting to-night.

OU'APPELLE.

There is a movement on foot in town to get a reading room and library established.

There was a heavy rain last night, but the sun is now shining again, so it is expected to do any harm to the grain crop. The farmers are now engaged in harvesting the dry land will do good to root and garden plots.

The work is being done under direction of Mr. Smith. The task is getting the wheat into the barns.

Harvesting is nearly completed in this neighborhood, and the general report is that the harvest will be good.

The government has decided to acquire a couple of acres of land in the Regina district for a certain time every day, that the public may come and see the work being done.

EDMONTON.

From the Bulletin, Sept. 1.

Grain was being cut at Lesser Slave Lake, Alta., Sept. 1st.

Butter sells at $25 cents to $35 cts. per pound and eggs at $30 cents to $40 cents per dozen.

F. S. Smith, who has a crop of wheat that will be ready to cut next week when the harvest judge estimates will be made, has been reported as having a small band of buffalo near his place. He says that he has heard that hunters succeeded in killing one.

He sells all his goods in town and has a large stock of goods.
